report_title: Mall Carts and Kiosks Industry Report
executive_summary: The Mall Carts and Kiosks industry, which includes a diverse range of specialty retail establishments in shopping malls, airports, sporting events and large department stores, has contended with difficult conditions. Declining mall traffic and rising external competition have threatened operators, which rely primarily on impulse purchases. Despite strong consumer spending and more aggressive tactics by shopping mall owners to earn revenue from underutilized spaces, the industry has struggled to maintain sales. Since 2020, the industry has been severely impacted by the pandemic outbreak. Overall, the cumulative effect of these trends is expected to result in a drop in sales. Revenue is expected to fall at a CAGR of 2.2% to $13.3 billion through the end of 2024, including growth of 2.4% in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling Mall Traffic Has Hampered Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry has dealt with a changing retail ecosystem that has threatened sales. Falling mall traffic has been the biggest factor working against the industry. Mall carts and kiosks rely heavily on mall foot traffic to drive sales, as they cannot easily attract shoppers. Lower foot traffic in malls has reduced chances for impulse purchases from kiosks and carts within malls, especially as everyday staples such as toilet paper and cleaning supplies are increasingly being delivered to consumers' doorsteps from companies like Amazon.com Inc.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Fueled Volatility, Heightening the Industry's Challenges
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented economic challenges and measures taken to mitigate the spread of the virus negatively impacted the industry. Most establishments were forced to shut down in response to mitigation efforts undertaken by governments and virus-weary consumers increasingly refrained from in-person shopping, limiting the foot traffic that industry mall carts and kiosks depend on. As consumers turned to online shopping, e-commerce sales grew more than 30.0% in 2020, contributing to a revenue decline of 27.4% in 2020. As the pandemic abated, revenue rebounded as consumers took to in-person shopping. In 2021 alone, revenue soared 24.6%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: With Competition Mounting, Mall Carts and Kiosks Have Looked to Differentiate Offerings
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With mounting competitive pressure, many establishments have focused on new service offerings to differentiate themselves. These added services have provided additional revenue streams and have helped lift overall revenue. For example, numerous phone accessory kiosks have added phone repair and battery replacement services, while personal care product carts have added makeup and hair styling consultations. Since most anchor retail stores and online channels do not offer such services, carts and kiosks have attracted and retained loyal customers through these offerings.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Malls Carts and Kiosks Will Benefit From Growing Consumer Spending
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With economies around the world exhibiting growth, consumers are expected to increase in-person shopping and generate significant foot traffic, which mall carts and kiosks depend on. This will benefit mall carts, which usually sell discretionary products based on impulse purchases. Establishments will continue to add service offerings to attract and retain consumers. Additional service offerings will also help operators compete with online retailers who cannot provide comparable services. However, this will also place a premium on higher-skilled workers to perform added services and promote customer loyalty.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition From Alternative Retail Channels Will Remain Steep
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite the rise in consumer spending, online retail channels will remain as popular as ever. As large retailers battle for the consumer dollar, boost their web presence and invest in faster delivery systems, more retail spending will be made with a mouse click or the tap of a smartphone screen. Consumers' continued shift away from malls and other traditional brick-and-mortar establishments will diminish merchandise sales made by mall carts and kiosks. There is little that these retailers can do, since they do not have the brand recognition to enter into the online selling space.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Establishments Will Continue to Look For New Sales Opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As competition heats up and mall traffic cools down, proprietors seek new revenue-generating markets. Airports, sporting venues, apartment complexes and office buildings are all likely to become larger hubs for retailers as they offer steady foot traffic for kiosks and carts to sell to.

industry_definition: This industry comprises establishments that retail various goods (excluding food) from kiosks and carts. Operators are most often located in indoor or outdoor malls or shopping areas. This industry also includes computer-based interactive or self-service kiosks.
key_trends: Mall carts and kiosks compete based on location to attract customers. Their relatively small size requires access to adequate inventory.
Inventory Requirements: Mall carts and kiosks typically carry limited inventory due to space constraints. They rely on frequent restocking, often daily, to maintain stock.

Competition: Establishments compete with brick-and-mortar retail shops and even more so, e-commerce establishments. Online shopping has reduced foot traffic in malls, undermining the position of mall carts and kiosks in the retail market.
COVID-19 Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic produced tremendous volatility across the industry. Regulations aimed at curbing the spread of the virus led to a precipitous slump in in-person shopping.
Industry Structure: The industry is highly fragmented. Most mall carts and kiosks operate at a single location and often by a single employee.
Regulations: Cigarette and tobacco product regulations apply to mall carts and kiosks. Tobacco products comprise more than one-third of specialty retail store sales.
Profitability: Profit margins vary among establishments based on the types of goods they retail. Still, they are relatively low across the board.

Regional Presence: Mall carts and kiosks flock to population centers to maximize potential revenue. As the most populated region of the US, the Southeast holds more establishments than any other region.
The Mid-Atlantic's large malls help drive establishments to the region: The Mid-Atlantic is home to four of the 10 largest malls in America.
Carts are the most common form of retail establishments: Mall carts benefit from their relatively low cost relative to kiosks.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Mall carts, sometimes known as retail merchandising units, are typically nonenclosed structures leased from shopping mall proprietors. Merchants supply these small structures, which are available for short-term leasing to retailers. Many landlords prefer this retail method because it minimizes the retailer's risk of going out of business. Compared with larger, store- and kiosk-occupying retailers, cart owners can often outlast their lease during adverse economic times. These operators have low overhead costs, lower inventory holding costs and fewer fees. Personal care and health products are the most popular products, followed by cell phone and accessory products. These goods are relatively inexpensive and favorable for impulse purchases.

The most significant difference between mall carts and mall kiosks is size. Kiosks are enclosed, enabling retailers to operate within them. Mall proprietors charge more to lease kiosks and retailers often demand longer lease terms to account for higher expenses. Whereas mall cart leases tend to last months, kiosk leases can be leased for years, giving the retailer fewer opportunities to test the market before committing to the location. Kiosk operators often begin their operations as cart owners and upgrade to larger establishments once their business model proves profitable. Established businesses and chains are likely to lease mall kiosks rather than storefronts as they provide a semi-permanent structure with less overhead and high levels of flexibility.

In addition to carts and kiosks, a variety of automated units dispense nonfood products, such as consumer electronics. These establishments are much less popular than other establishments. Vending machines have historically sold food and small amusement products such as rubber balls. However, they have expanded over time to sell shaving kits, infant products and consumer products. These upscale machines sell anything from MP3 players and phone chargers to upscale makeup, toys and shoes.

products_and_services.product_description: Apparel cart owners in this segment retail a variety of men's, women's and children's clothing items. However, these carts thrive primarily because of the ancillary services they provide, including airbrushing and silk screening. These operators can appeal to a wide range of consumers because of the high degree of customization offered by these services and their relatively low risk.

This segment includes selling products such as tablets, wearable technology, phone and laptop chargers and cases, digital cameras and other small personal electronic devices and accessories. Items in this category are highly discretionary and often purchased on impulse. Because of this, most operators retailing these items locate themselves in high-traffic areas to reach a larger number of consumers. Services are also included in this segment, including screen replacement, battery replacement and other repair services. These services have become increasingly popular and are often a way for small kiosks to compete. Many consumers look to kiosks for repair services as an alternative to product replacement.

This category includes video games, puzzles, books, movies, arts and craft kits, stuffed animals and numerous other products. This merchandise is sold through mall carts rather than traditional stores because it is less risky and requires fewer start-up costs. Seasonal pop-up shops from popular toy stores have helped offset the decline in demand from online retail. These stores benefit from low operating costs, as they are open during a short period of high demand.

This category includes perfumes, cosmetics, hair products and accessories, body oils, soaps and health supplements. Female consumers largely dominate this product segment, so operators tailor their operations to cater to shifting trends within the demographic.

This segment includes home décor items, prepackaged food, gift baskets, calendars, floral arrangements, pet care products, gift wrapping services and many other miscellaneous products and services. Items in this category are highly discretionary and often seasonal. The variety of products within this segment limits volatility as diminished demand for certain goods is typically matched by rising demand for others.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most products supplied by the Mall Carts and Kiosks industry are discretionary items. Therefore, a rise in household disposable income increases the propensity for consumers to purchase these goods, leading to growth in demand. Declines in the level of per capita disposable income pose a potential threat to the industry.

The industry benefits from growth in consumer confidence. During a recession, the inevitable spike in unemployment leads to declining consumption and confidence. Conversely, consumers will be more likely to spend money on discretionary retail purchases when consumer confidence is high. Growth in the consumer confidence index represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is the most populated region in the US, providing a broad pool of customers. Mall carts and kiosks are located in populated hubs, like cities and town centers, to boost foot traffic.

California houses the highest portion of the US population and the largest number of mall carts and kiosks. Mall carts and kiosks are generally clustered right outside of metropolitan areas. California has four of the largest 20 metro areas in the United States.

Consumers spend more on products at mall carts and kiosks than average in the Mid-Atlantic region. The region has several large, affluent cities where consumers have high disposable income levels. The Mid-Atlantic region houses four of the 10 largest malls in the United States by area. Shopping centers in this region typically have more kiosks per shopping center.
Florida has the highest concentration of establishments, which is indicative of shopping patterns within the state; cities like Miami are known for shopping.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Establishments are subject to regulations relating to the sale of tobacco, food services and lottery tickets. For instance, government permits or licenses are required to sell tobacco and lottery tickets.
Carts and kiosks are also subject to price regulation, laws that limit the hours of operation and legislation on wage rates, working conditions and citizenship requirements.

The 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act mandated the Federal Reserve to develop laws regarding debit card interchange fees and routing, which they finalized in October 2011.

Employment laws govern the hiring practices, wages and working conditions of staff at mall carts and kiosks. Owners must comply with minimum wage requirements, provide safe working environments and adhere to labor regulations such as youth employment guidelines, ensuring fair treatment of employees.
Local zoning laws dictate where mall carts and kiosks can be placed. These regulations ensure kiosks don't obstruct pedestrian traffic and adhere to the mall's aesthetic standards.

basis_points.basis_title: Location is key for attracting customers
basis_points.basis_description: Mall carts and kiosks compete based on location to attract customers. Their relatively small size requires access to adequate stock, as they often restock daily.

Establishments compete with brick-and-mortar retail shops and even more so, e-commerce establishments. Online shopping has reduced foot traffic in malls, undermining the position of mall carts and kiosks in the retail market.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry has long been fragmented. The dominance of independent establishments dates back to the industry's historical beginnings and persists because smaller companies can quickly adapt to changes.
Small companies can also compete effectively by acquiring superior locations or offering specialized merchandise and services.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Fragmented nature prevents high market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: Next, the fragmented nature of this industry makes it difficult for any single company to obtain significant market share.
The retail environment within malls can be volatile, with mall carts and kiosks frequently changing due to short-term leases and varying levels of business success.
Seasonal products and trends often dictate the existence of many carts and kiosks, leading to a constantly shifting market landscape that prevents high market share concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Costs are the Largest Cost Category
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are expected to account for 40.0% of revenue in 2024. Purchase costs for mall carts and kiosks are generally lower than in other retail industries, as their retail footprint is smaller.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Mall Carts and Kiosks Benefit From Lower Wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage costs are forecast to account for 36.9% of revenue in 2024. Mall carts and kiosks that provide services often hire skilled salespeople who demand higher wages.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Margins Vary, But Are Low All Around
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is expected to account for 5.5% of revenue in 2024. Profits vary among establishments because kiosks and carts sell a wide range of products with different purchase costs and selling prices.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although small specialty mall carts and kiosks rely more on labor than capital, wages are low. Few employees are needed to keep an establishment running.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue is sensitive to changes in consumer sentiment and per capita disposable income, as goods sold at carts and kiosks are highly discretionary

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Industry Has Endured Turbulence In Recent Years
volatility_points.volatility_description: Although consumers' income and confidence have trended upward, the COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented economic challenges.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: E-cigarettes are considered to be slightly less harmful than traditional cigarettes and have been marketed toward younger consumers. Small cigarette and tobacco retailers are expanding their e-cigarette inventories to capture this growing market.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators offer a diversified range of products, including seasonal products, in order to gain a competitive advantage over other businesses.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Most products sold by industry operators are discretionary, thus as the economy prospers consumers are more willing and able to spend on industry goods and services.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease equipment to reduce overhead costs?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators typically lease or rent space in shopping centers, which helps reduce overhead costs.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Wages are a significant expense for mall carts. Many operators are now offering electronic repair services, which require skilled employees.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The rise of e-commerce has hampered industry revenue over the past five years and is expected to remain a threat to the industry in the coming years.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: The industry has begun to include self-serving kiosks however the industry remains labor intensive.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The industry sells a wide array of products, which results in industry operators engaging with various trade associations.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: While the industry is moderately regulation, new regulations that impact industry revenue have not impacted profitability in recent years.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Given the nature of the business, customers pay at the time of purchase.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Industry turnover is a concern for nearly all mall cart and kiosk operators, particularly as many offer seasonal products.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels? What can you do to push out old stock? DO you employ FIFO or LIFO practices?
FAQs.answer: Operators should ensure that sufficient stock levels are maintained at all times given the limited space available and the trendy nature of the products.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How can you expand your offerings to these niches? Do you offer fad products?
FAQs.answer: Having access to niche markets helps hedge operations from external competition, particularly from shopping mall stores and other industry operators.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to ensure your products are presented well and clearly displayed?
FAQs.answer: Industry establishments should have effective layout and design, as well as good shelf management, using limited space to grab customers' attention.

FAQs.question: How will a continual rise in e-commerce activity affect your outlook? How can you effectively compete with these retailers? How can you improve sales?
FAQs.answer: As more consumers visit online retailers for their shopping needs, demand for kiosk and cart establishments will fall.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in consumer confidence affect your business? How can you entice consumers to buy when consumer confidence is low?
FAQs.answer: During times of recession, the inevitable spike in unemployment leads to declining consumption and confidence. Conversely, when consumer confidence is high, consumers will be more likely to spend money on discretionary retail purchases.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in per capita disposable income? Do you offer products for families with a wide range of disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: The majority of products supplied by the Mall Carts and Kiosks industry are discretionary items. Therefore, a rise in household disposable income increases the propensity for consumers to purchase these goods, leading to growth in demand.
